name: lignite mine operation | lignite | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/18420/documentation

The datasets represents the production if 1 Kg lignite for India. The data values like diesel consumption, spoil, electricity for the dataset is taken from annual reports and other environment statements which are mentioned in the particular exchange comments. Due to unavailability of india specific data, the data for water and various emissions to air and water have been taken from the global datasets - "Lignite mine operation"/GLO - 1994. ;The activity starts from extraction of lignite present under the rock to final loading into vehicles to be sent for transportation. Lignite is one of the major fuels used in India. It a premature variety of coal is a dark brown to black combustible mineral formed over millions of years by the partial decomposition of plant material subject to increased pressure and temperature in an airless atmosphere. In simple terms, lignite is a brown coal. In its natural form, lignite is porous, light in weight and contains a high percentage of moisture and volatile matters as compared to Fixed Carbon. Because of this, its transportation, over long distances is uneconomical.  Therefore, this fuel is ideally suitable for running lignite based power generation plant located close to pit head.;Estimated Lignite reserves in India as on 31st March 2016 were 44.59 Billion Metric Tonnes. The mining of Lignite in India is mostly concentrated in Rajasthan and Tamilnadu. Both of these contribute to almost 92.87 % of total lignite reserves in the country.;The major companies which are in to extraction of Lignite are Neyveli Lignite corporation (NLC - contributing to alomost 58 % of overall lignite production) , Gujarat Mineral Development Corporation (GMDCL contributes to almost 7 % of overall lignite production) , Barmer Lignite Mining Company Limited (BLMCL contrbutes to almost 6.6 % of overall Lignite Production) 

Mining process starting from brown coal, in ground.

This activity ends with 1 kg lignite at the lignite mine. This covers various details like electricity , diesel consumption for  lignite mining. Also details for spoil and land transformation and occupation details for operation and restoration of mine are taken into account.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/052:Mining of lignite/0520:Mining of lignite

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data Collected are collected over the years 2006 - 2016 , They are estimated to be valid till 2020. The data collected has been taken from the annual reports from 2014-15 and statistics of mines in India Volume - 1 (Coal ) for the year 2014 and several other environmental statements available for various mines in india
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The lignite mining in India is mainly concentrated in the states of Rajasthan and Tamilnadu which contributes to almost 93 % of overall Lignite reserves ;The dataset is representative of mining in the above area.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: At present open cast mining is being adopted for lignite mining throughout the world. Underground mining are not followed due to weak roof and floor condition, spontaneous combustion nature of lignite, existence of high pressure aquifer system  below lignite.;About 80% of total lignite reserves in the country occur below the depth of 150 meter and mining of this lignite is not economical with the present day technologies viz. continuous mining using Specialised Mining Equipment and Conventional mining using Shovel and Dumper. Though 20% of resources fall within 150m depths, part of the resource fall in high stripping ratio, thin and multiple seams, surface, constraints, environmental issues, etc. To exploit the deep seated lignite, technologies like underground coal gasification are to be developed and adopted.; Owing to low heat value of the mineral and high moisture content, higher productivity has to be achieved in the opencast mines with a compulsory pit head linkage to make lignite mining economically viable.;Neyveli Lignite Corporation: German excavation technology in open cast mining, using Bucket Wheel Excavators, Conveyors and Spreaders were used for the first time in the country in Neyveli Mine-I.;Gujarat Mineral Development Corporation Limited: Tadkeshwar Lignite mines have opencast mining Using Hydraulic excavators and dumper combination along with ancillary equipments such as Dozer, Water Sprinkler, Motor Grader etc.;Barmer Lignite Mining company limited has adoopted conventional Shovel Dumper combination available for opencast mining for both Kapurdi and Jalpia Mines
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: literature data:  Annual Report Neyveli Lignite Corporation 2015 - 16 , Final EIA report for Expansion of Mine 1A of Lignite Mines for Neyveli Lignite Corporation Limited, Statistics of Mines in India - Volume -1 (Coal) - 2014

exchanges.description:
Literature Data: The data is taken from Environment statement of VS Lignite Power Limited and GIPCL Mangrol Valia Lignite Mine. 50 % of land transformation is assumed for mineral extraction and 50 % of land transformation is assumed for dump site.
To calculate land occupation mine life was taken as 20 years as mentioned in the environment statment and additional 100 years were considered for revegetation of the mine.
Calculated value based on literature values and expert opinion. See comments in the parametres' comment field.

Literature Data: The data is taken from Environment statement of VS Lignite Power Limited and GIPCL Mangrol Valia Lignite Mine. 50 % of land transformation is assumed for mineral extraction and 50 % of land transformation is assumed for dump site.

Value taken from "lignite mine operation"/GLO - 1994 accessed 27 Nov 2017. The below comment has been retained from the same.          Estimation:                                                                                             Radon emissions arise out of the release of coal and overburden. If the overburden is loose (e.g. Rheinland) emissions during mining are low, because the gas release already happened. About 20 % of the radon concentration of coal plus twice the concentration are emitted via overburden, which corresponds to 12 Bq/kg coal. These figures are assumed to be valid for hard coal and could be lower for lignite. In the UCTE-area most of lignite is mined in seams with loose overburden. Thus, in this dataset it is assumed that one quarter of these emissions are emitted, which corresponds to 3 Bq/kg coal.

flow.name: Radon-222
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Value taken from "lignite mine operation"/GLO - 1994 accessed 27 Nov 2017. The below comment has been retained from the same.        Estimation:                                                                                                 Apart from spoil and lignite also huge amounts of water are mined. Figures for Germany amount to 6 m3/t. Water extraction has a large share of the total energy consumption of coal mining. Due to the fact that other opencast mines show smaller depths and lower delivery rates, it is assumed that the average value for water extraction may be lower. 

Estimation. Apart from spoil and lignite also huge amounts of water are mined. Figures for Germany amount to 6 m3/t. Water extraction has a large share of the total energy consumption of coal mining. Due to the fact that other opencast mines show smaller depths and lower delivery rates, it is assumed that the average value for water extraction may be lower.

exchanges.description:
Literature Data: The data is taken from Environment statement of VS Lignite Power Limited and GIPCL Mangrol Valia Lignite Mine. 50 % of land transformation is assumed for mineral extraction and 50 % of land transformation is assumed for dump site.
To calculate land occupation mine life was taken as 20 years as mentioned in the environment statment and additional 100 years were considered for revegetation of the mine.

Value taken from "lignite mine operation"/GLO - 1994 accessed 27 Nov 2017. The below comment has been retained from the same.        Estimation:                                                                                                     Due to the lack of information a rough estimation of emissions to water is made. For mining regions outside Germany (6 m3/t) a water elevation of 1 m3/t is assumed. In general a salinity degree of 1 g/l is estimated. According to Euler this figure represents an assumption and is likely to be higher; no differentiation between different kinds of salt was made. Furthermore it was assumed that 40 kg pyrite (FeS2) per ton pit coal are worn in overburden and are released untreated with ground water as Fe2+ and SO42-  into the discharge system. These are very rough estimations and are not based on literature sources but shall be included in the dataset. The potential effects of lowering the pH-value and leaching of micronutrients are not included in the dataset.

Value taken from "lignite mine operation"/GLO - 1994 accessed 27 Nov 2017. The below comment has been retained from the same.                        Estimation. These are very rough estimations and are not based on literature sources but shall be included in the dataset. The potential effects of lowering the pH-value and leaching of micronutrients are not included in the dataset.

Estimation:                                                                                                   Due to the lack of information a rough estimation of emissions to water is made. For mining regions outside Germany (6 m3/t) a water elevation of 1 m3/t is assumed. In general a salinity degree of 1 g/l is estimated. According to Euler this figure represents an assumption and is likely to be higher; no differentiation between different kinds of salt was made. Furthermore it was assumed that 40 kg pyrite (FeS2) per ton pit coal are worn in overburden and are released untreated with ground water as Fe2+ and SO42-  into the discharge system. These are very rough estimations and are not based on literature sources but shall be included in the dataset. The potential effects of lowering the pH-value and leaching of micronutrients are not included in the dataset.

Estimation based on available emission factors for Coal mining in India. 

Following are the emission factors available for India. Methane Emission factor for opencast mining in India (cubic meter / ton of coal mined) is 1.18 for mining operation and 0.15 for post mining activities (handling). 

The above emission factors are taken from GHG platform India 2005-2013 National Estimates - 2017 Series. These can be referred in a excel file available at http://www.ghgplatformindia.org/electricityenergy-sector  under the section Download: Phase 2 (2005- 2013) National Level Estimate.

The density of methane is taken as 0.68 Kg/cubic meter, the same value is taken while converting from meter cube to kg. The same is also mentioned in the above source. Also since lignite mining is only done through open cast mining the emission factors are considered only for open cast mining.

flow.name: Methane, fossil
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: Value taken from "lignite mine operation"/GLO - 1994 accessed 27 Nov 2017. The below comment has been retained from the same.          Estimation.                                                                                                  Due to the high water content, lignite has low dust emissions, compared to the overburden where high dust emissions can be expected. Barriers, green areas and water sprinklers are installed to avoid high dust emissions. A large part of emissions remain in the opencast mine and is deposited within the mining region. However, fine particles are emitted and result in dust exposure in the near surroundings. To estimate dust emissions for the UCTE-region a mining region with a diameter of 4 km and an annual mining output of 15 Mio. t are assumed. At the edge of the area 0,2 g/(m2*d) emissions and at a distance of 3 km 0.1 g/(m2*d) are assumed to be measured. At a distance of 6 km emissions are assumed to be insignificant. According to these assumptions annual dust emissions of 0,4 kg/t lignite are estimated. In UBA for lignite treatment 0,2 kg/t lignite during distribution and transport are estimated. In this dataset the previous approach is used because it can be assumed that total emissions in Europe are two times higher than the figures given in UBA.

flow.name: Particulate Matter, > 10 um
